titleStmt.title: Variants of the bound pronoun 3rd person plural masculine
titleStmt.author: Veronika Engler

sourceDesc.p: This is the feature-file for the 3rd person plural masculine bound pronoun.

revisionDesc.change: For EGY-___ there are no values found

wib:featureValueObservation.note: Middle-age and young speakers show only comunis form -(h)un
Middle-age and young speakers show only comunis form -(h)un
Also -hin attested as comunis form
Also -hin attested as comunis form
Also -hin and -hun attested as comunis forms
al-Qaṣīm has -hum
deduced from example
Deduced from examples
Initital h often assimilates regressively to (mainly) preceding vowel. When ʕ precedes, reciprocal assimilation usually yields ḥḥ, e.g. miḥḥum 'with them'.
Initital h is often assimilated to preceding voiceless vowels, e.g. ḥayyāttum 'their life'.
Initial h may assimilate to preceding voiceless consonants, e.g. ḥāṭṭum 'get them'.

In comparison to neighboring varieties, the initial h hardly ever assimilates, in fact, only two instances were recorded, e.g. btāʕittuw 'theirs' which is considered a Koine-form. When ʕ precedes, the ʕḥ sequence usually assimilates to ḥḥ.

In comparison to neighboring varieties, the initial h hardly ever assimilates, in fact, only two instances were recorded, e.g. btāʕittuw 'theirs'. When ʕ precedes, the ʕḥ sequence usually assimilates to ḥḥ.
Initital h is often assimilated to preceding voiceless vowels, e.g. ḥayyāttum 'their life'.
Initital h is often assimilated to preceding voiceless vowels, e.g. ḥayyāttum 'their life'.
Initital h often assimilates regressively to (mainly) preceding vowel. When ʕ precedes, reciprocal assimilation usually yields ḥḥ, e.g. miḥḥum 'with them'.
Initital h is often assimilated to preceding voiceless vowels, e.g. ḥayyāttum 'their life'.
Initial h may assimilate to preceding voiceless consonants, e.g. ḥāṭṭum 'get them'.
-hum in a very few instances
